title: Flying with Thanksgiving food? TSA dishes rules for traveling with foodstuff this holiday season; Thanksgiving travel tips from the TSA include which food items can be carried on, and what has to be checked with your bags.
text:
"Here's some food for thought. If it's a solid item, then it can go through a checkpoint," TSA said in a statement on Wednesday. "However, if you can spill it, spread it, spray it, pump it or pour it, and it's larger than 3.4 ounces, then it should go in a checked bag."

And with Thanksgiving around the corner, many recent TSA travel inquiries have been related to prepared food, perishables and spices. So here is a list of items that TSA will allow as a carry-on, and those that must be in a checked bag.

Food you can carry-on

* Baked goods, including homemade or store-bought pies, cakes, cookies, brownies and other sweet treats.

* Meats, such as turkey, chicken, ham and steak â€”frozen, cooked or uncooked.

* Stuffing, cooked or uncooked, in a box or in a bag.

* Casseroles, such as traditional green beans and onion straws, or something more exotic.

* Macaroni and cheese, whether it's already cooked in a pan, or you're traveling with the ingredients to cook it at your destination.

* Fresh vegetables, like potatoes, yams, broccoli, green beans, Brussels sprouts, cauliflower, beets, radishes, carrots, squash and greens.

* Fresh fruit, such as apples, pears, pineapple, lemons, limes, cranberries, blueberries, strawberries, bananas and kiwi.

* Candy.

* Spices.

Food that must travel in a checked bag

* Cranberry sauce, including homemade or canned sauces that are spreadable.

* Gravy, including homemade or gravy that comes in a jar or can.

* Wine, champagne and sparking apple cider.

* Canned fruit or vegetables, as they have liquid in the can.

* Preserves, jams and jellies, since they are also spreadable.

* Maple syrup.

Keep in mind that the TSA has an entire list of items that travelers are allowed to bring on flights year-round under the "What can I bring?" section of its website. Additionally, there is an official TSA Twitter account called @AskTSA that responds to most tweets inquiring about what items can be moved through TSA, answering between 8 a.m. and 6 p.m. EST.

So why the rules around food? Earlier this month, the TSA created a viral post post detailing a situation when a traveler attempted to conceal a gun inside a raw chicken. Guns are not permitted to bring as a carry-on, and are only allowed in checked bags if certain safety precautions are taken.

The TSA said it may screen as many as 2.5 million passengers at checkpoints in the U.S. during the day before Thanksgiving on Wednesday, Nov. 23, and it may see more than 2.5 million passengers on Sunday, Nov. 27 as travelers return home.

Over the last three years, the Sunday after Thanksgiving was the most crowded travel day from the Friday before Thanksgiving to the Wednesday after, according to the TSA.

Flying with Thanksgiving food? TSA dishes rules for traveling with foodstuff this holiday season
